content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (<math overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math> points, suggested time <math overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> minutes) Students perform an experiment with a battery and four resistors, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>A</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>B</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> </math>, and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>D</mtext> </math>. The resistance of resistors <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>A</mtext> </math> and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> </math> is <math alttext="R sub A, equals R sub C, which equals R" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mi>R</mi> </math>. The resistance of resistors <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>B</mtext> </math> and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>D</mtext> </math> is <math alttext="R sub B, equals R sub D, which equals 2 R" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>R</mi> </math>. The students create the two circuits shown above and measure the potential differences <math alttext="delta V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta V sub B" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>Δ</mtext> <msub> <mi>V</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi> </msub> </math>, <math alttext="delta V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math>, and <math alttext="delta V sub D" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>Δ</mtext> <msub> <mi>V</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi> </msub> </math> across resistors <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>A</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>B</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> </math>, and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>D</mtext> </math>, respectively. (a) From greatest to least, rank the magnitudes of the potential differences across the resistors. Use “<math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"> <mn>1</mn> </math>” for the greatest magnitude, “<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>” for the next greatest magnitude, and so on. If any potential differences have the same magnitude, use the same number for their ranking. ____ <math alttext="delta V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> ____ <math alttext="delta V sub B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> ____ <math alttext="delta V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math> ____ <math alttext="delta V sub D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></msub></math> Justify your answer.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (<math overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math> points, suggested time <math overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn></math> minutes) Students perform an experiment with a battery and four resistors, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>A</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>B</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> </math>, and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>D</mtext> </math>. The resistance of resistors <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>A</mtext> </math> and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> </math> is <math alttext="R sub A, equals R sub C, which equals R" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mi>R</mi> </math>. The resistance of resistors <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>B</mtext> </math> and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>D</mtext> </math> is <math alttext="R sub B, equals R sub D, which equals 2 R" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>R</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>R</mi> </math>. The students create the two circuits shown above and measure the potential differences <math alttext="delta V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta V sub B" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>Δ</mtext> <msub> <mi>V</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi> </msub> </math>, <math alttext="delta V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math>, and <math alttext="delta V sub D" overflow="scroll"> <mtext>Δ</mtext> <msub> <mi>V</mi> <mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi> </msub> </math> across resistors <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>A</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>B</mtext> </math>, <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>C</mtext> </math>, and <math overflow="scroll"> <mtext>D</mtext> </math>, respectively. (a) From greatest to least, rank the magnitudes of the potential differences across the resistors. Use “<math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"> <mn>1</mn> </math>” for the greatest magnitude, “<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>” for the next greatest magnitude, and so on. If any potential differences have the same magnitude, use the same number for their ranking. ____ <math alttext="delta V sub A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> ____ <math alttext="delta V sub B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math> ____ <math alttext="delta V sub C" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math> ____ <math alttext="delta V sub D" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></msub></math> Justify your answer.

In another experiment, the students have a capacitor with unknown capacitance <math alttext="C sub U" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub></math>. They want to determine <math alttext="C sub U" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub></math> by using a battery of potential difference <math alttext="4.5 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and several other capacitors of known capacitance. They create circuits with the battery, the unknown capacitor, and one of the capacitors of known capacitance. The students wait until the capacitors are fully charged and then record the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub known" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>known</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> across the known capacitor and the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub U" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>U</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math> across the unknown capacitor. Their data are shown in the table on the following page. Known Capacitance of Capacitors <math alttext="in micro farads" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>μ</mtext><mtext>F</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="delta V sub known, in volts" overflow="scroll"><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mtext>known</mtext></msub><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></math> <math alttext="delta V sub U, in volts" overflow="scroll"><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mtext>U</mtext></msub><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></math> <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></math> <math alttext="0.91" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.91</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3.53" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.53</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="300" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3.74" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.74</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.51" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.51</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3.95" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.42" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="4.06" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.06</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="600" overflow="scroll"><mn>600</mn></math> <math alttext="0.36" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.36</mn></math> <math alttext="4.17" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.17</mn></math> (b) i. Calculate the amount of charge on the capacitor of known capacitance of <math alttext="200 micro farads" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> μF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the students’ experiment.
ii. Briefly explain why the data in the table provide evidence that the capacitors are connected in series.

iii. Briefly explain why connecting the capacitors in parallel would not provide enough information to determine the capacitance of the unknown capacitor if the only measuring device available is a voltmeter.

(c) The students want to produce a linear graph of the data so that the capacitance <math alttext="C sub U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>C</mi><mtext>U</mtext></msub></math> of the unknown capacitor can be determined from the slope of the best-fit line for the data.i. Indicate two quantities that could be plotted to produce the desired graph. Use the empty columns of the data table in part (b) to record any values that you need to calculate. Vertical axis _________________ Horizontal axis _________________
ii. Label the axes below and provide an appropriate scale with units. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the axes and draw a best-fit line.

iii. Using your best-fit line, determine the capacitance of capacitor <math alttext="C sub U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>U</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
